title: एक मुक्त टंक / Ek Mukta font are Open Source
content:
EK Latin and Ek Devanagari are Open Source now and available under the name Ek Mukta on Google fonts.

comments.content: The only exhaustive Devanagari font with 7 weights is available for web and print.
The only exhaustive Devanagari font with 7 weights is available for web and print.

Congratulations.  
Nice design!  
Please explain your reasons for providing it as an open source font from Google. Is it a webfont as well as one for printing?  
Good luck

Thanks Vladimir.  
We wants to make the Ek Mukta font available to everyone who can't afford to buy quality fonts (with extensive glyph set).  
Ek Mukta fonts are web and print fonts.

To better undersand a "gesture", I usually follow a few links and may also read comments in source files. Those source files can be obtained at the URL [https://github.com/girish-dalvi/Ek-Mukta](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317092635/https:/github.com/girish-dalvi/Ek-Mukta) (click on "download zip"); the README.md file is worth reading, with explicit thanks for "support and encouragement". In the [CONTRIBUTORS.txt](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317092635/https:/github.com/girish-dalvi/Ek-Mukta/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.txt) file it is written that the copyright holders are listed in the [AUTHORS.txt](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317092635/https:/github.com/girish-dalvi/Ek-Mukta/blob/master/AUTHORS.txt) file, which contains Girish Dalvi and Ek Type. The link [Girish Dalvi](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317092635/http:/www.idc.iitb.ac.in/~girish/index_en.html) may help seeing the link between the Industrial Design Center IIT Bombay and Ek Type.

Thanks. This is fascinating - one more instance of what I think of as an international trend for all scripts to evolve what, for want of a better term, may be called a 'san-serif' style:

Strokes historically made by a stylus, brush, pen etc. become simplified. Extra decorative flourishes and artefacts specific to the technique used to produce the line are deleted (serifs in Latin script, the extra stroke on top of verticals in Arabic, the fuzzy ending of a brush-stroke in Japanese and Chinese script). More importantly a generic form of any given letter is adopted distilled from the many calligraphic or decorative script styles in use. A 'hidden' requirement may be to make each glyph visibly different from the rest, whilst retaining a unified harmonious style for the font as a whole. Unfortunately most modern Arabic "Sans" fonts mimic Latin lettering for no good reason, and ignore their own splendid traditions, in that many font letters now use the same design element, creating a regimented look and are often illegible.

I first learned about all this in the 1960's from Eric Gill's book "Typography". It inspired me start a project (almost finished now 50 years later, my AlQuds font) to convert Arabic into Gill Sans style type. I corresponded with the late Hiromo Hara the Japanese designer and there he had developed such a Sans style. Early non-European Sans-Serif adopters were Thai scripts... and now we learn about the trend on the subcontinent. Best of luck.
Thanks Michel for reading the README.md :)
